intro: Lepidaploa decumbens, commonly known as the creeping lepidaploa, is a low-growing perennial plant native to South America. It features small, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. The plant produces tiny, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale green, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Lepidaploa decumbens thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in forest understories or along stream banks. Its fibrous roots and dense growth habit make it a useful plant for erosion control in suitable habitats.
